event.desc: From childhood, Mary chose to remain a virgin and dedicate her life to fasting, prayer, charity, and pilgrimage.
Mary travelled to Golgotha, where she prayed and fasted for three days.
As Mary prayed and fasted the custodians of Golgotha tried to drive her away, then let her remain once they saw that she was praying.

personGrp.persName: The custodians of Golgotha who tried to drive away Mary

event.desc: Mary engaged in ecstatic prayer and fasting for three years in Golgotha, drawing crowds of people who marvelled at her and asked for prayers and blessings.

personGrp.persName: The persons of Golgotha who asked for prayers from Mary

event.desc: Mary, disturbed by the attention of those who gathered to admire her asceticism in Golgotha, left the holy site and went east to get away from the crowds and live a holy life.
Euphemia took a husband and had one daughter, who was trained in the religion.
Euphemia dedicated her life to asceticism and charitable works.
Euphemia and her daughter wove goat's wool and used half of the proceeds to feed the poor, the sick, the prisoners, and the disabled in their community.
Euphemia and her daughter labored tirelessly in their charitable endeavors.
Euphemia always refused charity for herself and her daughter, and so they never ate except from the proceeds of their labor in their house.
A great religious persecution took place and many holy men and women were expelled from their convents

personGrp.persName: Those who were expelled from their convents during the persecution.
The adversaries who expelled the holy men and women from their convents during the persecution.

event.desc: Euphemia hired rooms to shelter 10-20 people who had been expelled from their convents during the persecution.
Euphemia went around to all of the wealthy people in the city and asked for donations to distribute to the poor.

personGrp.persName: Persons of high position who provided donations to the poor at the request of Euphemia

event.desc: Euphemia helped those outside of the city as well and took the sick to the superintendents of the hospitals for care.

personGrp.persName: Superintendents of hopitals who received and cared for the sick at the request of Euphemia

event.desc: After thirty years of service, Euphemia aroused the envy of those who held power in the Church.
Those who held power in the Church tried unsuccessfully to force Euphemia to become a communicant in their impiety.
Euphemia's persecutors imprisoned her for thirty days, then exiled her because her imprisonment caused unrest in the community.
Euphemia and her daughter went into exile and were persecuted for five years.
Euphemia returned to Amida and stayed at a certain gentleman's house.

person.persName: A certain gentleman who gave Euphemia shelter in Amida

event.desc: The adversaries found out that Euphemia returned to Amida and sent a summons for her.
Euphemia fell ill, blessed her daughter, and died.
A messenger came bearing a letter from Mary to Maria
Mary passed away ten days before Euphemia

person.persName: Messenger who delivered a letter to Maria

event.desc: Mary completed sixty years in the course of her sanctity
Euphemia completed thirty-five years in the course of perfection -- thirty administering to saints and five in persecution, which led to martyrdom.
Maria followed closely in the footsteps of her saintly mother and aunt
